displayName: Mummification - The Art of Eternal Preservation
timing: Upon death, taking 70 days total (40 days of desiccation, 30 days of preparation and wrapping)
steps: Purification: Body washed with palm wine and Nile water in the per-nefer (House of Beauty)
Evisceration: Organs removed through incision in left flank; brain extracted through nose
Organ preservation: Liver, lungs, stomach, intestines placed in four canopic jars
Desiccation: Body covered and stuffed with natron salt for 40 days
Cleansing: Dried body washed, anointed with oils, frankincense, and myrrh
Stuffing and shaping: Body cavities filled with linen, sawdust, or sand to restore form
Wrapping: Hundreds of yards of linen bandages applied with resin, amulets placed between layers
Mask placement: Funerary mask applied to identify the deceased to their ka
Opening of the Mouth: Ritual to restore senses and animate the mummy for afterlife
Coffin sealing: Mummy placed in nested coffins and sarcophagus
Funeral procession: Journey to tomb with professional mourners and offerings
Tomb sealing: Final placement with grave goods, food, and protective spells
tools: Canopic jars with four sons of Horus stoppers
Natron salt (natural desiccant from Wadi Natrun)
Peseshkef (ritual implement for Opening of the Mouth)
name: Mummification
participants: Sem Priest (performs Opening of the Mouth)
procedure: Mummification was performed in specialized workshops called the wabet (pure place) or per-nefer (house of beauty). The process began immediately after death to prevent decomposition in Egypt's hot climate. Embalmers, working under the patronage of Anubis, first purified the body with sacred water. The brain was removed through the nose using hooks, as it was considered unimportant. Internal organs were extracted through a left-flank incision made with a ritual obsidian blade - the person making this cut was symbolically chased away as having violated the body. Organs were preserved separately in canopic jars protected by the four sons of Horus. The emptied body was packed with natron salt and left for 40 days to desiccate completely. After drying, the body was washed, stuffed to restore lifelike appearance, and anointed with precious oils. Wrapping required hundreds of yards of linen, with protective amulets and spells placed between layers. The heart scarab ensured the heart would not testify against the deceased at judgment. Finally, the Opening of the Mouth ceremony restored the mummy's ability to eat, drink, breathe, and speak in the afterlife.
deities: Anubis - God of embalming, inventor of mummification, guides souls
Osiris - Lord of the dead, first mummy, model for resurrection
Thoth - God of wisdom, provided magical spells of protection
Isis and Nephthys - Divine mourners, protected the mummy
Four Sons of Horus - Imsety, Hapy, Duamutef, Qebehsenuef (canopic protectors)

metadata.historicalPeriod: Predynastic through Ptolemaic Egypt (c. 3500 BCE - 30 BCE)
metadata.primaryRegion: Ancient Egypt, throughout the Nile Valley

description: Mummification represents ancient Egypt's most elaborate and enduring funerary practice, a sophisticated 70-day process designed to preserve the body for eternal life. The Egyptians believed that the ka (life force) and ba (personality) required an intact physical form to which they could return. According to mythology, the god Anubis invented mummification when he preserved the body of Osiris after his murder by Set, establishing both the technique and the theological justification for the practice. The process combined practical preservation techniques - evisceration, desiccation with natron salt, and application of resins - with elaborate religious rituals including spells, amulet placement, and the crucial Opening of the Mouth ceremony that animated the mummy for afterlife existence. Different levels of mummification existed based on wealth, from the elaborate royal process taking months to simpler treatments for commoners. This practice persisted for over 3,000 years, producing the thousands of mummies that have fascinated the modern world and provided unprecedented insight into ancient Egyptian medicine, religion, and daily life.
purpose: preservation of body for afterlife, enabling reunion of ka and ba, ensuring eternal existence
materials: Natron salt (primary desiccant from Wadi Natrun)
Linen wrappings (hundreds of yards per mummy)
Amulets (scarabs, djed pillars, Eye of Horus, etc.)
prohibitions: Heart must never be removed - seat of intelligence and soul, needed for judgment
Bodies of criminals and enemies could be denied mummification
Sacred spells must be recited correctly or lose power
Impure persons forbidden from handling the mummy
Tomb violation brings curse and divine retribution
The 70-day period must be observed (mirrors Sirius' absence)

sections.origins: Natural mummification in Egypt's arid desert sands preceded artificial techniques by millennia. The earliest Egyptians buried their dead directly in the sand, where the heat and dryness naturally preserved bodies. When elite burials began using coffins and tombs that prevented this natural desiccation, decomposition became a problem. This necessitated the development of artificial mummification techniques by the Old Kingdom (c. 2600 BCE). The mythology attributed the invention to Anubis, who preserved Osiris's murdered body, making the god the patron of embalmers and the archetypal model for resurrection.
sections.attributes: Egyptian mummification was unique in its theological integration - each step had religious significance beyond mere preservation. The 70-day duration corresponded to the period Sirius (associated with Isis) was invisible below the horizon. The four canopic jars were protected by the four sons of Horus, each safeguarding a specific organ. The heart remained in place because it would be weighed against Ma'at's feather in the afterlife judgment. Amulets provided magical protection during the dangerous journey through the underworld. The wrapping pattern itself encoded protective spells.
sections.significance: Mummification was central to Egyptian religion's promise of eternal life. Without an intact body, the spiritual components of the person (ka, ba, akh, shadow, name) had no anchor and could not achieve blessed afterlife. This belief drove the enormous investment of resources in mummification and tomb construction that characterized Egyptian civilization. The practice also developed Egyptian understanding of anatomy, chemistry, and preservation techniques that influenced later Mediterranean medicine.
sections.impact: Mummification profoundly influenced subsequent cultures. Greek visitors like Herodotus documented the practice, spreading knowledge throughout the Mediterranean. Roman Egypt continued mummification with Greco-Roman stylistic additions. Early Christians in Egypt mummified saints' bodies. The practice influenced medieval European approaches to relics. Modern study of mummies has revolutionized our understanding of ancient disease, diet, genetics, and culture. The mummy remains one of ancient Egypt's most iconic and enduring legacies.
